title: Guy Harvey witnesses his artwork coming to life on Norwegian...
text:
It’s the biggest canvas that marine wildlife artist Guy Harvey has ever encountered.
It’s the hull of Norwegian Escape, spanning 1,000 feet from bow to stern. The ship, under construction at the Meyer Werft shipyard in Germany, will debut this fall in Miami.
Marine wildlife artist Guy Harvey gets a close-up of the hull of Norwegian Escape, which features his artwork. The ship debuts in November in Miami. (Contributed by Norwegian Cruise Line) Harvey visited the shipyard to see how his artwork is taking shape on the cruise line’s newest and largest ship.
The process of creating the design involves using a laser that projects the artwork onto the hull. A team then outlines the art, pencilling in the lines and taping the edges. Paint is applied by hand.
The design features Harvey’s signature sailfish, along with Caribbean sea life such as sting rays, sea turtles, whale sharks and tropical fish.
Fincantieri CEO Giuseppe Bono (left) hosted the steel cutting ceremony for Silver Muse with Silversea Chairman Manfredi Lefebvre d’Ovidio at the Genoa-based shipyard. (Contributed by Silversea Cruises) The 4,200-guest Norwegian Escape will sail seven-day cruises year-round from PortMiami to the Eastern Caribbean beginning Nov. 14.
BOOK LAUNCH: Carnival Cruise Line and its partner, Dr. Seuss Enterprises, recently teamed up to celebrate the release of the new Dr. Seuss book, “What Pet Should I Get?” with celebrity book readings.
In Florida, Tampa Bay Rays all-star Evan Longoria hosted youngsters from the Boys & Girls Club aboard Carnival Paradise while it was docked in Tampa.
Evan Longoria, the all-star Tampa Bay Rays third baseman, reads the new Dr. Seuss book, “What Pet Should I Get,” to Boys and Girls Club youngsters aboard the Carnival Paradise while the cruise ship is docked in Tampa. Carnival features a Seuss at Sea family program aboard many of its vessels. (Contributed by Carnival Cruise Lines) Following Longoria’s reading, the children and their chaperones joined Seuss characters, including The Cat in the Hat, Sam I am, and Thing 1 and Thing 2, for the cruise line’s Green Eggs and Ham Breakfast. The popular event is offered on the line’s exclusive Seuss at Sea program.
In conjunction with the book release, Carnival is matching Longoria’s donation of $100 to Pet Pal Animal Shelter for every home run he hits during the 2015 season. The cruise line is also donating to the Tampa Bay chapter of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
LEARN, HAVE FUN: The countdown clock is running on www.paralegalcruise.com , counting the days, hours and minutes until Brilliance of the Seas sets sail from Tampa.
Paralegals, their family and friends are invited aboard the 2,500-guest Royal Caribbean ship Feb. 18 as it sails to Cozumel, Mexico on a four-night voyage that includes two days at sea.
The paralegal program format combines live seminars with take-home self-study programs for Continuing Legal Education credits. A career seminar, along with one-on-one career guidance and resume review will also be offered.
But it’s not all work. The agenda will include a number of social events for participants, including a meet and mingle cocktail party.
Information about registration, prices, available staterooms and a list of FAQs can be found on the website.
CUTTING STEEL : Silversea Cruises celebrated the start of construction of Silver Muse on July 24 with the cutting of the first steel at Fincantieri’s shipyard in Genoa, Italy.
Silversea’s chairman Manfredi Lefebvre d’Ovidio co-hosted the event with Giuseppe Bono, CEO of Fincantieri.
Set to debut in the spring of 2017, Silversea’s new 596-guest flagship will join the luxury cruise line’s eight-ship fleet.
Although it’s still too early to book the new ship, and specific details about Silver Muse are not yet available, learn more about the cruise line at www.silversea.com.
